title: Dollar General Corporation ( DG ): A Bull Case Theory
description: Dollar General Corporation ( DG ): A Bull Case Theory
text:
We came across a bullish thesis on Dollar General Corporation on RM Capital Partnership’s Substack by RM Capital Partnership. In this article, we will summarize the bulls’ thesis on DG. Dollar General Corporation's share was trading at $108.76 as of August 29th. DG’s trailing and forward P/E were 20.14 and 19.68 respectively according to Yahoo Finance.
fikri-rasyid-ezeC8-clZSs-unsplash
Dollar General (DG) exemplifies the power of a simple, resilient model: small stores located close to home, offering essential consumables at consistently low prices. With over 20,500 stores across 48 states, DG is often the only general merchandise option in rural America, where 75% of households live within five miles of a location. Its business is built around quick, $10 fill-in trips, with 80% of revenue driven by staples like snacks, groceries, cleaning supplies, and health & beauty.
While margins on consumables are thin, non-consumables and private brands provide profit leverage, and initiatives like DG Fresh have lowered costs while expanding fresh and frozen offerings. Competitors like Walmart, Amazon, and Temu cannot replicate DG’s niche: immediate-need, small-basket, paycheck-to-paycheck households seeking convenience and affordability. Walmart may win on unit price, but DG’s proximity and speed keep it competitive, while Amazon and Temu are disadvantaged by order minimums and product mix.
Inflation and tariffs pose challenges, yet they also reinforce DG’s value, drawing households down from higher-cost channels. Its moat rests on capital-efficient small-box economics, deep alignment with low-income shoppers, and a consumables-led merchandise mix that drives recurring trips. Management, led by returning CEO Todd Vasos, is stabilizing operations after execution missteps, focusing on shrink reduction, remodels, and higher-margin growth levers like pOpshelf and digital media. At a $24B market cap and ~12× FCF, DG trades at a discount that underestimates its earnings power. Margin recovery and buybacks could drive double-digit compounding, making DG a durable compounder with substantial long-term upside.
Previously we covered a bullish thesis on Dollar General Corporation (DG) by Tyler Moody in October 2023, which highlighted margin compression but argued stabilization would restore profitability. The company’s stock price has appreciated approximately 35% since our coverage. This is because execution and resilience improved. The thesis still stands as structural economics remain intact. RM Capital Partnership shares a similar view but emphasizes management reset and long-term compounding.

title: Goldman top stock picker warns AI next phase may not justify the hype around its stocks
description: Goldman top stock picker warns AI next phase may not justify the hype around its stocks
text:
AI may be dominating the stock market, but its future growth is far from guaranteed.
"This trade is very nonlinear and volatile in nature," Goldman Sachs analyst Eric Sheridan said on Yahoo Finance's Opening Bid.
The AI market is still developing, moving through distinct phases that have each presented unique investment opportunities and risks, Sheridan added.
The first phase focused heavily on infrastructure — building out data centers, cloud networks, and powerful chips to support AI's rapid growth. But now the focus is moving toward the "application layer," where companies are figuring out how to use AI in real-world products and services.
The shift is critical because there are "very different skews" between how AI is being adopted by consumers versus businesses, per Sheridan.
"People are much more likely to adopt AI in their consumer computing habits than their enterprise computing habits," he explained, adding that consumers see less risk in AI and don't feel it will hurt their ability to earn money.
However, the adoption of AI by large companies is riskier. "Enterprises have to operate within strict budget requirements," Sheridan said. "You also run into some friction on the employee side with respect to how they use AI in their own individual workflows."
These differences in adoption could affect the growth potential of AI stocks. While AI applications for consumers are advancing rapidly, businesses may take longer to integrate AI on a wide scale.
In a note to clients, Goldman analyst Ryan Hammond wrote that the AI stock market suggests valuations may already be ahead of themselves.
AI-exposed stocks rallied by 32% in 2024, though they remain below the levels seen during the tech bubble and 2021. Nonetheless, Hammond cautions that the eventual slowdown in hyperscaler capital expenditures could create risks for these stocks.
"Timing this inflection is challenging," he noted, adding that the next few quarters will be critical in determining whether AI-driven infrastructure companies can continue to deliver the growth investors are expecting.
Meta (META) has remained bullish on the technology, with plans to invest $600 billion in the US through 2028 to develop AI infrastructure.
Sheridan is cautious about the long-term financial impact, though he pointed out the company is already seeing results. Meta is among several digital platforms — including Alphabet (GOOGL, GOOG) and Pinterest (PINS) — that could benefit from AI disrupting traditional advertising.

title: Tech investor Ross Gerber says AI is nothing like the dot - com bubble and Warren Buffett was wrong to pare Apple
description: Tech investor Ross Gerber says AI is nothing like the dot - com bubble and Warren Buffett was wrong to pare Apple
text:
Tech investor Ross Gerber says AI is nothing like the dot-com bubble — and Warren Buffett was wrong to pare Apple
-
The AI craze is a long way from the excesses of the dot-com bubble, Ross Gerber told Business Insider.
-
Valuations aren't absurd, top companies are printing money, and AI will be transformative, he said.
-
The tech investor said Warren Buffett erred by paring his Apple stake and has an outdated portfolio.
Tech investor Ross Gerber said the AI boom is nothing like the dot-com bubble — and Warren Buffett was wrong to slash his Apple stake.
The cofounder and CEO of Gerber Kawasaki Wealth and Investment Management told Business Insider that he "traded through" the internet mania around the turn of the millennium. The AI craze "just isn't comparable," he said.
The S&P 500's 20%-plus returns in 2023 and 2024 may seem unsustainable, but the benchmark index delivered similar returns for five years from 1995 through 1999, Gerber said. He started his career with "perfect timing" in 1994, he added.
When Magnificent Seven companies trade at lofty earnings multiples, they're considered overvalued "because people have never seen numbers that big," Gerber said. But the tech investor said their valuations aren't out of sync with their businesses, calling their profitability "just insane."
Alphabet generated more than $100 billion in net income last year, while Nvidia's profits rose by over 50% year on year last quarter.
Gerber, whose firm invested in Tesla and Nvidia around a decade ago and now manages north of $3 billion in client assets, added that AI had enormous potential to increase productivity and earnings. He contrasted it with smartphones, which he called "counter useful" and "time wasters."
Gerber says Berkshire Hathaway has a 'portfolio of the past'
Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has taken little interest in the AI frenzy, even selling nearly 70% of its Apple stake in the 18 months up to June 30.
Gerber told Business Insider he thought that Buffett may have pared the position because it had become too "heavy" — it was worth $174 billion or around half of Berkshire's entire stock portfolio at the end of 2023.
But Gerber said he still thought the sale was "dumb" because "it was a huge realized gain that is taxable, and there's nothing that he could invest in that's better than Apple in the long term," he said.
Gerber said Apple would "continue to mint profits for a very long time and be a part of our kids' lives forever," adding that he didn't see any "wisdom" in selling.

title: Alpha Metallurgical Resources , Inc . ( AMR ): A Bull Case Theory
description: Alpha Metallurgical Resources , Inc . ( AMR ): A Bull Case Theory
text:
We came across a bullish thesis on Alpha Metallurgical Resources, Inc. on The Small Cap Strategist’s Substack by Strategist and Architect. In this article, we will summarize the bulls’ thesis on AMR. Alpha Metallurgical Resources, Inc.'s share was trading at $149.19 as of August 29th. AMR’s trailing P/E was 6.24 according to Yahoo Finance.
Copyright: vyacheslavsvetlichnyy / 123RF Stock Photo
Alpha Metallurgical Resources (AMR) represents a classic deep-value opportunity where the market has mispriced the company due to short-term pessimism. While analysts expected a catastrophic Q2 loss of $2.76 per share, AMR reported a loss of just $0.38, highlighting exceptional operational execution in a challenging metallurgical coal market. This outperformance was driven by the company achieving its best quarterly cost of coal sales since 2021, reducing costs to $100.06 per ton through a 10% increase in productivity and disciplined cuts in maintenance and supply expenses.
Despite weak coal prices, the market is overlooking two critical aspects that underpin AMR’s investment case. First, the company has a fortress balance sheet, with $556.9 million in liquidity and minimal long-term debt of $5.8 million as of June 30, 2025, providing significant resilience and a margin of safety that positions AMR to outperform less financially stable peers. Second, the company has a coiled spring of capital returns, with approximately $400 million remaining on its $1.5 billion share repurchase authorization.
While buybacks were paused amid market softness, management indicated plans to restart opportunistically, creating an imminent catalyst that could meaningfully reduce the public float at depressed valuations. Overall, AMR offers investors access to a best-in-class, operationally superior metallurgical coal producer at trough-cycle valuations. The combination of strong operational leverage to potential coal price recovery and the near-term share repurchase catalyst creates a highly asymmetric risk-reward profile, making AMR a compelling investment for those recognizing the disconnect between market perception and underlying fundamentals.
Previously we covered a bullish thesis on Alpha Metallurgical Resources, Inc. (AMR) by Margin of Sanity in May 2025, which highlighted the company’s fortress balance sheet, disciplined buybacks, and operational leverage to coal prices. The stock has appreciated around 20% since our coverage as the thesis played out. Strategist and Architect shares a similar view but emphasizes Q2 operational outperformance and the near-term catalyst of restarting share repurchases.

title: Veeva Systems Inc . ( VEEV ): A Bull Case Theory
description: Veeva Systems Inc . ( VEEV ): A Bull Case Theory
text:
We came across a bullish thesis on Veeva Systems Inc. on Compounding Your Wealth’s Substack by Sergey. In this article, we will summarize the bulls’ thesis on VEEV. Veeva Systems Inc.'s share was trading at $269.20 as of August 29th. VEEV’s trailing and forward P/E were 55.39 and 35.7 respectively according to Yahoo Finance.
Copyright: melpomen / 123RF Stock Photo
Veeva Systems (VEEV) delivered a robust Q2 2025 with revenue of $789.1 million, up 16.7% YoY and 4% QoQ, beating estimates by 2.8%, and non-GAAP EPS of $1.99, up 4.7% versus expectations. Operating margin expanded to 44.7% (+3.3 pps YoY) and free cash flow margin surged to 29.4% (+16.1 pps YoY), reflecting operational efficiency across subscription and professional services. Subscription revenue reached $659.2 million (+17.4% YoY) with gross margin of 86.2%, while professional services contributed $129.9 million (+13% YoY, GM 33.4%). Despite net new ARR declining 10.6% YoY, the company maintained strong execution with a CAC payback period of 9.3 months.
Veeva’s Vault CRM is a major growth driver, with nine of the top 20 pharma companies committed and two live in major markets, positioning VEEV ahead of Salesforce in top-tier adoption. About 300 customer migrations are underway, expected to peak in 2026–2027, which should bolster revenue and margin expansion. Clinical products also performed strongly, with R&D subscriptions showing their best sequential growth in two years and full adoption of the Trial Master File across top pharma. AI integration into Vault and other suites is poised to enhance efficiency, workflow automation, and long-term market expansion.
Strategic partnerships with IQVIA, Microsoft, and SAP further strengthen product integration, while the horizontal CRM pilot offers optional expansion beyond pharma. Despite minor adoption lags in Compass and lumpiness in Crossix usage-based revenue, management raised FY guidance to $3.134–3.140 billion (+14.2% YoY), reflecting confidence in the $6 billion five-year revenue target. Veeva combines high-margin recurring revenue, structural adoption advantages, and emerging AI-driven growth, presenting a compelling investment case with both near- and long-term upside.
Previously we covered a bullish thesis on Veeva Systems Inc. (VEEV) by Francesco Ferrari in March 2025, highlighting its high-margin recurring revenue, strong cash flow, and $5 billion net cash position. The stock has appreciated around 12% since coverage as execution remained strong. Sergey shares a similar thesis but emphasizes Q2 2025 results, Vault CRM adoption, and AI-driven growth as key near-term catalysts.

title: Ramaco Resources , Inc . ( METC ): A Bull Case Theory
description: Ramaco Resources , Inc . ( METC ): A Bull Case Theory
text:
We came across a bullish thesis on Ramaco Resources, Inc. on The Small Cap Strategist’s Substack by Strategist and Architect. In this article, we will summarize the bulls’ thesis on METC. Ramaco Resources, Inc. 's share was trading at $25.93 as of August 29th. METC’s trailing and forward P/E were 9.47 and 5.49 respectively according to Yahoo Finance.
nikolay-kovalenko-66r7PAK1Qy0-unsplash
Ramaco Resources Inc. (METC) stands out as a unique investment that cannot be analyzed like a typical coal company. The firm is executing a strategic pivot to become a “dual platform” company, combining low-cost metallurgical coal operations with the mining and processing of rare earth elements (REEs) at its Brook Mine in Wyoming. This mine represents the first new REE project in the U.S. in over 70 years, positioning Ramaco to challenge China’s dominance in minerals critical for defense, electric vehicles, and high-tech manufacturing.
Brook Mine’s geology offers a rare advantage: the REEs are commingled with soft coal and clay, making extraction easier, cheaper, and free from the radioactivity issues common to conventional hard-rock REE deposits. Market valuation, however, fails to reflect this transformative potential. A preliminary economic assessment by Fluor Corporation assigns the project a pre-tax NPV of $1.2 billion—nearly equal to Ramaco’s total enterprise value of $1.7 billion—implying that investors are attributing little to no value to the REE asset.
The recent $200 million upsized public offering further de-risks the thesis, funding the REE project’s acceleration toward commercialization and signaling management’s confidence. The investment case is thus a sum-of-the-parts arbitrage: investors gain a stable, cash-generating metallurgical coal business while effectively receiving a call option on a fully-funded, strategically vital rare earths operation. Ramaco illustrates that true alpha emerges not from deep specialization but from connecting seemingly unrelated opportunities—linking regulatory developments, technology trends, and cyclical industry dynamics to identify undervalued, multi-dimensional growth prospects.
Previously we covered a bullish thesis on Ramaco Resources, Inc. (METC) by Unemployed Value Degen in October 2024, which highlighted the company’s low-cost metallurgical coal operations, growth potential, and the strategic value of its rare earth element discovery. The stock has appreciated approximately by 141% since our coverage as the thesis played out. The Small Cap Strategist shares a similar view but emphasizes the fully-funded acceleration of the REE project.

title: Hyperliquid Slashes Trading Fees by 80 % Ahead of Native Stablecoin Launch
description: Hyperliquid Slashes Trading Fees by 80 % Ahead of Native Stablecoin Launch
text:
Decentralized perpetual futures exchange Hyperliquid is preparing to roll out its first native stablecoin while slashing spot trading fees by 80%, in a move designed to boost liquidity and deepen its hold over the decentralized finance (DeFi) derivatives market.
The exchange announced on Discord that the next network upgrade will cut taker fees, maker rebates, and user volume contribution for spot pairs between two quote assets by four-fifths.
Alongside the fee changes, Hyperliquid has reserved the USDH ticker for a new dollar-backed stablecoin, which will be allocated through a validator vote.
Teams seeking to issue USDH must submit proposals including their deployment address, with the winning bid to be selected by validator quorum in a fully on-chain process.
USDH Stablecoin Aims to Anchor Hyperliquid’s Expanding DeFi Suite
USDH is intended as a “Hyperliquid-first” compliant stablecoin that will integrate across the platform’s ecosystem, including perpetuals, spot markets, staking, and protocols such as Kinetiq, Hypurrfi, and Hyperlend.
The exchange described stablecoins as the “backbone of any L1,” with USDH expected to serve as a settlement layer that can expand total value locked (TVL) across DeFi applications.
Source: Hyperliquid Discord
Revenue is expected to accrue internally through mint and burn fees, collateralized lending flows, and native on- and off-ramps, creating a self-reinforcing “stablecoin flywheel.”
The launch comes as regulators in the United States, including the Treasury Department, seek feedback on the GENIUS Act, a legislative framework for stablecoin oversight.
Hyperliquid’s decision to put the stablecoin under validator control highlights its bid to align with regulatory expectations while reinforcing its decentralized governance model.
Monthly trading volume surged to $383 billion, lifting its annualized revenue to $1.25 billion and cementing a 70% market share among DeFi perpetual platforms. Cumulative trading volume has now exceeded $2.57 trillion.
Source: DefiLlama
Despite its scale, Hyperliquid operates with just 11 employees, relying on automation and smart contracts to handle functions such as settlement, reconciliation, compliance, and customer operations.
The lean model has produced efficiency ratios far ahead of traditional payment firms. PayPal, which employs 29,000 staff, processes $1.6 trillion annually, while Visa requires 28,000 workers for $13 trillion. By comparison, Hyperliquid manages over $330 billion in yearly volume with a fraction of the headcount.
Much of the platform’s dominance is attributed to HyperEVM, its custom Layer 1 blockchain, which eliminates gas fees for trades while maintaining fully on-chain order books.
The model delivers centralized-exchange performance with decentralized transparency, a combination that has helped the exchange outpace competitors such as Robinhood and Bitstamp in recent months.
Trading activity has peaked at $29 billion in 24-hour volume, generating as much as $7.7 million in daily fees.
Hyperliquid’s governance token, HYPE, has rallied sharply alongside its financial performance. The token traded at $47.43 at the time of writing, up 4% over the past day and 7% in the past week, according to CoinGecko.
Source: CoinGecko
HYPE has gained 21% in the past month, 209% in six months, and nearly 95% year-to-date. The surge coincides with the exchange’s revenue growth, reinforcing the link between governance demand and ecosystem expansion.
$HYPE Gains 4.5% in August Despite Hyperliquid’s Mid-Summer Outage
Hyperliquid suffered more than 30 minutes of downtime in July after its API servers became overloaded. Trading halted at 14:10 UTC as users reported delays in order execution, with complaints quickly surfacing in the platform’s Discord channel.
Although Hyperliquid’s status page did not immediately show issues, the team later confirmed the outage and described it as a “major” event.
Trading resumed at 14:47 UTC after engineers stabilized the servers. In a statement, the exchange said the disruption stemmed from a sharp traffic spike rather than a hack or exploit.
The halt created brief price divergences as traders were unable to close positions. Hyperliquid has since pledged to add monitoring tools and safeguards to prevent a repeat.
Later in August, the exchange reimbursed nearly $2 million to users affected by the brief outage.
The token powers Hyperliquid’s on-chain perpetuals DEX, which operates a Central Limit Order Book (CLOB) and supports smart contracts via HyperEVM. It is used for gas, staking, and governance.
The project’s tokenomics tie protocol fees to both an Assistance Fund and the HLP pool, which buy back $HYPE. Current revenue distribution stands at 54% and 46%, respectively.
Speculation around HYPE intensified after former BitMEX CEO Arthur Hayes predicted the token could deliver 126x returns by 2028. Hayes’ thesis assumes Treasury-backed stablecoins will reshape global banking, driving trillions in deposits into compliant DeFi venues like Hyperliquid.
Institutional interest is growing. Hayes himself acquired 58,631 HYPE tokens worth $2.6 million, while 21Shares listed exchange-traded products on Switzerland’s SIX Exchange.
Analysts say expansion into tokenized assets and fintech integrations could further strengthen Hyperliquid’s position in the coming years.

title: US jobs market slumps in blow to Trump
description: US jobs market slumps in blow to Trump
text:
America’s jobs market has slowed dramatically in a fresh blow for Donald Trump.
The US economy added just 22,000 new jobs in August – less than a third of the 75,000 roles expected by analysts, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. America’s unemployment rate also rose from 4.2pc to 4.3pc.
After the figures were published, US government borrowing costs dipped as investors bet the weak jobs data will increase the likelihood of interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve.
Yields on 10-year Treasuries – which move inversely to prices – fell to 4.095pc from 4.16pc, the lowest since Mr Trump’s liberation day tariffs in April while 30-year yields fell from 4.853pc to 4.824pc.
In Britain, yields on gilts, which are closely tied to US government borrowing costs also dipped. The rates on 30-year bonds fell from 5.574pc to 5.531pc.
The gloomy jobs figures may further provoke the ire of the President, who has previously criticised US jobs data as “rigged”. Last month he sacked Erika McEntarfer, the head of the BLS, after figures showed downwards revisions in the May and June jobs figures.
On Thursday, Mr Trump appeared to shrug off the figures ahead of their publication. “The real numbers that I’m talking about are going to be whatever it is, but will be in a year from now,” he said.
Statistics for June were also revised down again on Friday. Instead of growth of 14,000 in June, the US saw non-farm payrolls shrink by 13,000. However there was a small upwards revision for the July numbers.
The non-farm payrolls data are the latest numbers in a slew of data that points to a slowdown in the US jobs market as Mr Trump’s sweeping trade tariffs and rapid policy changes push businesses to put hiring decisions on hold.
Separate figures from ADP on Thursday showed private sector hiring halved in August, totalling just 54,000. This was down from 106,000 in July and was well below the 75,000 economists had expected.
BLS figures show the number of long-term unemployed has increased by 385,000 over this year and now stands at 1.9m.
Mr Trump has nominated EJ Antoni, chief economist at the Right-wing Heritage Foundation, to take over Ms McEntarfer’s role.
05:34 PM BST
Signing off...
Thanks for joining us today.
That’s all for this live blog, but you can read all the latest news and comment on the economy here.
05:15 PM BST
FTSE 100 closes down as US jobs market stalls
The FTSE 100 gave back early gains to close lower today as a weak US jobs report raised fears the world’s biggest economy was slowing.
“The [US] labour market is in a precarious position,” said analysts at Wells Fargo, putting the Federal Reserve in a position “where it will imminently start cutting the federal funds rate”.
The FTSE 100 index closed down 0.1pc, at 9,208.21. It had earlier traded as high as 9,253.53.
The FTSE 250 ended 0.5pc higher, at 21,575.54, and the AIM All-Share finished up 0.5pc, at 765.63.
For the week, the FTSE 100 rose 0.2pc, the FTSE 250 fell 0.1pc and the AIM All-Share firmed 0.2pc.
In New York, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.5pc, the S&P 500 is 0.4pc lower, while the Nasdaq dropped 0.1pc.
Thomas Feltmate, senior economist at TD Economics, said: “There’s no escaping that the [US] labour market is softening, and quickly.
“Fed officials have become increasingly concerned about the downside risks to the labour market, and [today’s] report will not assuage those fears.”
Wells Fargo said the jobs engine, that has been integral to US economic growth defying expectations for the past four years, is “stalling”.
“With elevated risk of further downward revisions, the recent pace of hiring is dangerously close to crossing into negative territory, where job market weakness quickly becomes self-reinforcing,” the broker warned.
04:46 PM BST
Cost of UK government debt slides after US jobs figures
The yield on gilts – the effective interest rate on UK government debt – slid this afternoon, after spiking earlier in the week.
The fall came after weak US jobs numbers raised hopes of American interest rate cuts.
US rates act as a drumbeat through Western economies.
The yield on 30-year gilts dropped 1.3pc to 5.505pc, while the 10-year gilt yields fell 1.6pc to 4.647pc.
04:16 PM BST
Wall Street falls back from record highs on slowdown fears
Wall Street’s main indexes eased from record highs this afternoon after concerns about a US slowdown outweighed optimism about interest-rate cuts.
Data showed the US economy created only 22,000 jobs last month compared to an estimate of 75,000 additions, confirming that labour market conditions were softening and making a stronger case for an interest-rate cut later this month.
“This is more of a recessionary jobs report than not. It doesn’t indicate that we’re necessarily in a recession now, but it definitely is more in the negative column than it is in the positive column,” said Kevin Gordon, senior investment strategist at Charles Schwab.
“If they’re (the Fed) is cutting in response to a weakening labour market because it’s getting away from them, that is initially not a bullish setup for the stock market.”
The three major US stock indexes had scaled fresh peaks early in the afternoon, but the gains petered out.
The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones are down 0.6pc, while the Nasdaq has lost 0.4pc.
04:09 PM BST
JP Morgan says UK’s black hole heading towards £30bn
JP Morgan has warned that rising UK bond yields could push the black hole in Britain’s public finances up towards £30bn.
It comes after yields on Britain’s 30-year gilts rose to as much as 5.748pc earlier this week.
The investment bank said: “There are several factors behind the rise in yields seen over the course of this year, of which fiscal concerns are only are one. But with a a Budget date now having been set for Nov 26, attention is turning to the size of the likely tightening that will bring and the precise choice of measures the Chancellor will opt for.
“Higher yields tilt the risks around our £20-30bn estimate of the size of the fiscal deterioration to the upside.
“The Chancellor has again reiterated that the rules are ‘non-negotiable’, highlighting the likelihood of a tightening of comparable magnitude. But the form that will take remains unclear.
“While higher taxes appear set to account for the lion’s share, some of these may be deferred to future years while upfront measures focus on savings with modest immediate growth impact. There is still some scope to announce deferred spending cuts in order to meet the medium term rules (e.g. in 2029/30) and calls for spending reductions to fill more of the gap increased this week.”
03:38 PM BST
Dollar dives after US jobs numbers
The dollar fell sharply against major peers this afternoon after monthly jobs data showed that American employers hired fewer workers than expected. This likely guarantees a Federal Reserve interest rate cut.
The US currency fell 0.8pc against a basket of six other global currencies, including the pound.
“The data is giving evidence of what was feared, which is that what companies have experienced throughout the year because of changes in trading policy has added costs when it comes to tariffs,” said Juan Perez, director of trading at Monex USA in Washington.
“These costs can only be absorbed for so long and what is being manifested is that companies are struggling with hiring.”
US government bond yields also fell. The yield on benchmark US 10-year notes fell to 4.081pc from 4.160pc yesterday.
“It’s definitely not a good story for the US dollar and it’s not a good story for the United States because what today truly establishes is that we are experiencing very serious stagflation,” Mr Perez added.
Stagflation refers to high inflation accompanied with unemployment and stagnant demand.
03:29 PM BST
Trump hits out at Federal Reserve
Donald Trump has lashed out at Federal Reserve chairman Jay Powell for not cutting interest rates after surprisingly bad US jobs numbers.
Mr Trump said on Truth Social: “Jerome ‘Too Late’ Powell should have lowered rates long ago. As usual, he’s ‘Too Late!’.”
Mr Trump has been making aggressive demands for interest rate cuts for months, calling Mr Powell a “numbskull” and trying to sack Fed Governor Lisa Cook.
The Fed has kept rates on hold all year as it waits to see the impact of Mr Trump’s tariffs, which are expected to drive up inflation.
02:57 PM BST
Wall Street climbs to more records
US stocks are rising further into record heights this afternoon after the latest disappointing signal on the job market bolstered expectations of interest rate cuts.
The S&P 500 climbed as much as 0.5pc and added to its all-time high set the day before. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is 0.3pc and the Nasdaq is 0.6pc higher.
The action was much stronger in the bond market, where Treasury yields tumbled after a report from the US Labor Department said employers across the country hired far fewer workers in August than economists expected.
The disappointing numbers followed last month’s weaker-than-expected update, along with other lacklustre reports in the intervening weeks. Traders now are betting on a 100pc probability that the Fed will cut its main interest rate at its next meeting on Sept 17, according to data from CME Group.
Such cuts can give a kickstart to the economy and job market, but the Fed has held off on them so far this year because they can also give inflation more fuel.
“This week has been a story of a slowing labour market, and today’s data was the exclamation point,” according to Ellen Zentner, chief economic strategist for Morgan Stanley Wealth Management.
02:42 PM BST
Gold hits fresh record after dismal US jobs numbers
The price of gold jumped to a fresh record after poor US jobs numbers increased bets that the Fed will cut interest rates.
Gold, which does not generate interest, is more attractive when the American central bank lowers rates.
The metal rose 0.8pc to as much as $3,586.82 an ounce.
02:31 PM BST
‘Trigger’ could set of UK fiscal crisis, warns economist
The conditions are in place for a crisis in the Government’s finances, a top economist has warned.
All that is needed now is a trigger, according to Ruth Gregory at Capital Economics.
Global investors could be shocked by anything from the Government breaking the borrowing rules, to a bump in interest rates which makes Britain’s near-£3tn debt look unsustainable.
“Many of the conditions which have led to fiscal crises in the past are now in place. This does not mean a fiscal crisis in the UK is imminent or inevitable. The missing ingredient is a trigger,” said Ms Gregory.
“If a UK fiscal crisis does erupt, it’s as likely to come from a change in perceptions or personnel as economic data or policy. This underlines the need for the government to continue to commit to fiscal discipline to keep the bond market onside.”
She listed seven potential such triggers.
Any attempt to break or change the fiscal rules – set just last year by Rachel Reeves – “could be perceived as a waning commitment to fiscal discipline, adding to the sense of nervousness about the UK’s perilous fiscal position and leading to sharp increases in borrowing costs.”
Similarly a long-term failure to get borrowing under control risks undermining credibility, causing more wobbles in debt markets.
If the Chancellor is sidelined or ditched, that could be taken as a sign the Government is abandoning any semblance of fiscal responsibility.
Runaway inflation and stagnant growth are another danger, as is “a vicious cycle” of rising debt costs which force the Government to borrow more just to pay the interest bill.
A Reform UK victory might also scare investors, if the opposition party does not explain how it will fund its plans, while contagion from a crisis abroad - perhaps in France, where the Government is likely to fall next week - could also worsen Britain’s predicament.
02:19 PM BST
Trump’s trade war ‘failing to reshore production’
America’s manufacturing sector has shed 78,000 jobs so far this year in a clear sign that Donald Trump’s trade war is failing to “bring jobs back” to the US.
The US lost 12,000 manufacturing jobs in August, contributing to a 25,000 decline in overall goods producing roles. Jobs in wholesale trade also fell by 11,700.
Bradley Saunders, of Capital Economics, said: “This confounds hopes of a tariff-led reshoring renaissance.”
02:16 PM BST
Doge helps cut 100,000 US government jobs
Nearly 100,000 government jobs have been lost since the Department of Government Efficiency (Doge) started making huge cuts at the start of the year.
Federal government employment fell by 15,000 in August and was down by 97,000 since January, BLS figures showed.
The impact of the Doge cuts has been delayed because employees who are on paid leave or are receiving ongoing severance pay are counted as employed in the BLS survey.
02:09 PM BST
Jobs market ‘has headed off a cliff-edge’
The US labour market “has headed off a cliff-edge”, Capital Economics has warned.
Bradley Saunders, of the research consultancy, said: “August’s Employment Report confirmed that the labour market has headed off a cliff-edge.”
America’s three-month average jobs growth is now just 29,000, just a fraction of the average monthly jobs growth of 184,000 seen across 2024.
02:01 PM BST
Tesla board recommends record $1tn package for Musk
Tesla is promising to award Elon Musk a $1tn (£740bn) payday if he makes the electric car maker the most valuable company of all time.
The company unveiled a new pay award scheme on Friday that will hand him hundreds of millions of shares if he can hit a string of ambitious milestones, including making Tesla worth $8.5tn over the next decade.
By 2035, Mr Musk would also have to have sold 1m AI robots and have 1m self-driving robotaxis on the road.
The deal would multiply Mr Musk’s existing $378bn (£280bn) net worth, which already makes him the world’s richest person by a wide margin, and make him the world’s first trillionaire.
01:51 PM BST
Trump says India and Russia appear ‘lost’ to ‘deepest, darkest China’
Donald Trump has said India and Russia seem to have been “lost” to China after their leaders met with Chinese President Xi Jinping this week, expressing annoyance at New Delhi and Moscow as Beijing pushes a new world order.
“Looks like we’ve lost India and Russia to deepest, darkest, China. May they have a long and prosperous future together!” Mr Trump wrote in a social media post accompanying a photo of the three leaders together at Xi’s summit in China.
Xi hosted more than 20 leaders of non-Western countries for the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) in the Chinese port city of Tianjin, including Russian president Vladimir Putin and Indian prime minister Narendra Modi.
Asked about Mr Trump’s post, India’s foreign ministry told reporters in New Delhi that it had no comment.
01:46 PM BST
Wall Street raises bets on US interest rate cuts
S&P 500 and Nasdaq futures have risen before the New York Stock Exchange opens properly this afternoon,
Markets are reacting to a weaker-than-expected non-farm payrolls reading which has raised investor bets on interest-rate cuts.
Traders increased bets that there could be as many as three quarter of a percentage point rate cuts by the end of the year.
A US Labor Department report showed non-farm payrolls increased 22,000 in August, compared with an estimate of a 75,000 rise, according to economists polled by Reuters.
01:36 PM BST
Trump shrugged off jobs numbers in advance
US employers added just 22,000 jobs last month as the labour market continued to cool under uncertainty over President Donald Trump’s economic policies.
The Labor Department said this afternoon that hiring decelerated from 79,000 in July. The unemployment rate ticked up to 4.3pc, the Labor Department reported Friday.
When the department put out a disappointing jobs report a month ago, an enraged President Donald Trump responded by firing the economist in charge of compiling the numbers and nominating a loyalist to replace her.
Talking to reporters Thursday night at a dinner with wealthy tech executives, Trump had seemed to shrug off whatever hiring numbers would come out Friday. “The real numbers that I’m talking about are going to be whatever it is, but will be in a year from now,’’ the president said.
01:24 PM BST
Investment bank warns over UK politicians
An American investment bank has warned over the willingness of British politicians to stomach tax and spending reforms.
Mohit Kumar, chief economist and strategist for Europe at Jefferies, said: “Our worry for the long end in the UK and France is not just about the current deficit picture, but about the willingness of politicians to deliver unpopular fiscal reforms,” said Mohit Kumar, chief economist and strategist for Europe at Jefferies.
It comes in a week when the cost of long-term debt spiked.
The yield (effectively the interest rate) on 30-year gilts hit 5.748pc on Wednesday. Germany, the benchmark for the eurozone, is currently paying 3.329pc on its 30-year bunds.
12:56 PM BST
Global stocks surge ahead of US jobs data
US markets are expected to open up later today ahead of crucial jobs data that could pave the way for further interest rate cuts.
Futures on the S&P 500 were up 0.3pc while Nasdaq futures were up 0.5pc ahead of markets opening later this afternoon after hitting record levels at the close on Thursday.
Investors are looking ahead to US payroll data later this afternoon, which is expected to show a cooling jobs market in America.
A weaker jobs market should be good news for investors, as it provides ammunition for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates.
The FTSE 100 was up around 0.3pc at lunchtime while the European Stoxx 600 was also up 0.3pc.
12:07 PM BST
Housing Secretary and Deputy Prime Minister Angela Rayner to resign
Angela Rayner, the Deputy Prime Minister and Secretary of State for Housing, is to resign from the government, according to multiple reports, amid a row over whether she paid enough stamp duty on a house purchase in Hove.
Ms Rayner, who was in charge of Labour’s planning reforms and its house-building blitz, will leave after disclosures in The Telegraph she had not paid enough tax when buying a new flat.
The Labour deputy leader had been responsible for waving through a series of infrastructure, housing and data centre projects for the government. But the government faced major hurdles to reaching its target for building one million new homes.
Separately, Sky News reported on Friday that Baroness Poppy Gustafsson, the Investment Minister, was planning to leave the government. The former Darktrace boss had been tasked with helping to attract businesses to Britain.
You can see all the updates on our politics live blog today.
11:54 AM BST
ONS apologises over botched data releases
The head of the Office of National Statistics (ONS) has apologised for its delayed and incorrect retail sales update in July amid growing doubts over the reliability of UK’s official economic data.
James Benford, a former Bank of England director who joined as head of the ONS in June, this morning acknowledged a major error in how it was seasonally adjusting retail figures.
In a blog post, he said: “I apologise both for the delay to this release and the error in how we have been seasonally adjusting these data.”
The failure to properly account for seasonal changes in how retailers report their figures, which can be tied to major holidays such as Easter and Black Friday that boost sales, meant the ONS was forced to revise down its quarterly growth data from the start of the year.
It revised down the growth rate in retail sales in the first quarter of 2025 from 1.3pc to 0.7pc and up in the second quarter from 0.2pc to 0.3pc.
Mr Benford said: “We will be conducting a full lessons-learned exercise and will improve our processes and procedures to make sure the error will not be repeated.”
The ONS said it planned to “put more resources behind work to improve economic statistics and to bring more transparency on how these plans are progressing” after a series of errors and revisions in its data releases.
10:52 AM BST
Shoppers at risk of higher prices as Budget looms, retail bosses warn
Shoppers have been warned they face higher prices amid fears Rachel Reeves could hammer retailers with further tax rises at her Budget in November.
The British Retail Consortium (BRC), which represents the UK’s biggest retailers, said any further tax rises on the industry also risked store closures and job losses.
It came as official data showed a 0.6pc rise in retail sales in July, compared with a month earlier, but fell 0.6pc during three months to July on the previous quarter.
However, the BRC said the increase made “little dent” at a time when retailers were burdened with higher taxes and labour costs.
Dr Kris Hamer, from the BRC, said: “Unfortunately, this level of sales growth makes little dent on the £7bn of new costs that retailers are having to shoulder following last year’s Budget.
“With a date now sent for the next Budget, government must ensure that no additional tax is levied onto retailers, or else many will be forced to make difficult decisions around raising prices, store closures, and jobs.”
Retailers raised fears that with an autumn Budget scheduled for November 26, they could face a sharp fall in spending just as they get ready for the crucial Christmas trading period.
Nicholas Found from Retail Economics said despite an increase in retail sales in July, spending on homeware and fashion had become heavily reliant on promotions rather than a boost in consumer demand.
He said: “Sales momentum across categories is patchy beneath the surface, including food facing renewed pressure from price rises.”
The figures were published by the Office for National Statistics (ONS) on Friday after they delayed releasing the data by two weeks “to allow for further quality assurance”.
The statistics body apologised for errors in its data and made corrections to retail sales figures from earlier in the year.
The ONS revised down its figures for the volume of retail sales in the six months to June from 1.7pc to 1.1pc.
The change came after the statistics body uncovered an error in how it seasonally adjusts the data.
10:30 AM BST
Reeves accused of wasting billions in taxpayer cash with costly debt binge
Rachel Reeves has been accused of wasting taxpayers’ money through an “arrogant” approach to borrowing from international debt markets.
Economists believe the Chancellor could save billions of pounds by the end of the decade if she copied the US treasury and opted to borrow more money via cheaper, short-term debt.
Instead, the Government continues to raise billions by borrowing over 10, 20 and 30-year terms that lock in high borrowing costs for decades.
09:54 AM BST
ONS grapples with reliability concerns
Experts have raised concerns about the reliability of data from the ONS after the statistics body made revisions to retail sales figures released earlier this year.
Errors in the way the ONS produces seasonally adjusted retail sales figures had caused it to delay the release of the figures by two weeks.
Matt Swannell, the chief economic advisor to EY ITEM Club, said: “It’s hard to have much confidence in the data when such fundamental errors have been made, and the revisions are so significant.”
The ONS then made significant revisions to retail sales figures from the first six months of the year after it uncovered an error with how it calculated seasonally adjusted sales.
Rob Wood, chief UK economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, said: “Errors are unwelcome and likely reflect ONS resources being stretched too far.
“Getting the data right in the first place is crucial for building confidence in official statistics, but almost as important is admitting an error and correcting the problem as soon as possible.”
The ONS has also experienced issues with its labour market data as responses to its key survey have declined.
09:33 AM BST
London markets update
The FTSE 100 has risen 0.3pc this morning as defence and aerospace companies provide a boost to the blue-chip index.
Housebuilders Barratt Redrow and Berkeley Group helped to push the FTSE 100 higher after Berkeley Group maintained guidance for the current financial year.
The FTSE 250 also made gains in early morning trading, climbing 0.4pc. However, it came under pressure from luxury retailer Burberry, which fell 2.4pc.
Oil prices continued to edge lower ahead of an OPEC+ meeting on Sunday. Traders expect the group to announce in increases to oil production.
The price of Brent crude, the international benchmark, fell 0.4pc to $66.75 per barrel.
09:15 AM BST
Britain’s housing market faces potential headwinds
The UK’s housing market is facing headwinds as it grapples with rising borrowing costs and a cooling labour market, warns an economist.
Martin Beck, economist at WPI, said the increase in the UK’s borrowing costs risked putting pressure on the housing market.
It comes after long term borrowing costs climbed to 5.75pc on Wednesday morning, a 27 year high. Following some jitters in the bond market they have settled at 5.56pc today.
Mr Beck said: “The headwinds are clear. Mortgage rates remain elevated by the standards of most of the last 15 years and rising bond yields are already pushing up the cost of fixed-rate loans.
“The jobs market is softening, consumer sentiment is fragile and speculation over property tax hikes in November’s Budget may cause some potential buyers to delay.”
08:42 AM BST
House prices rise for third month in a row
House prices rose for the third month in a row as mortgage rates eased and continued wage growth helped sales remain resilient.
The value of a typical home rose 0.3pc in August compared to July, according to the Halifax house price index.
Average house prices stood at £299,331, which was up 2.2pc compared to the same time last year.
Amanda Bryden of Halifax said: “The story of the housing market in 2025 has been one of stability. Since January, prices have risen by less than £600, underlining how steady the market has been despite wider economic pressures.
“While the wider economic picture remains uncertain, the housing market has shown over recent years that it can take these challenges in its stride.”
The rise in house prices comes as the number of homes for sale hit a 10-year high in June.
Halifax said there continues to be challenges with the affordability of homes however there are “signs of improvement” as lenders offer more flexible affordability assessments and mortgage rates ease.
House prices have risen more slowly in recent months following a rapid increase at the start of 2025 when buyers sought to take advantage of the final months of stamp duty break on property purchases.
07:45 AM BST
Sunny weather provides boost to retail sales
Retail sales rose by 0.6pc in July, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS), as shoppers splashed out on clothing and footwear.
Good weather and the women’s Euro football tournament helped to drive shoppers to spend more during the month.
The rise in monthly retail sales beat analysts’ expectations of a 0.2pc increase.
The increase in sales is a boost for retailers as they grapple with an increase in labour costs after the rise in employers’ national insurance contributions came into effect in April.
Despite the monthly increase, in the three months to July retail sales volumes fell 0.6pc, as households cut back on spending in May.
The new retail sales figures come after the ONS delayed releasing the data by two weeks “to allow for further quality assurance”. The statistics body has come under scrutiny for the reliability of its data.
06:50 AM BST
5 things to start your day
-
Reeves accused of wasting billions in taxpayer cash with costly debt binge | Chancellor urged to copy US treasury and borrow more money via cheaper, short-term loans
-
Britain’s biggest tour operator slashes flights as tax fears hit bookings | Package holiday airline Jet 2 has cut 200,000 seats to winter sunspots amid fall in demand
-
Fed official faces criminal investigation over mortgage scandal | Trump ordered governor’s removal from US central bank as he pushes for lower interest rates
-
Britain’s biggest wind farm operator sues US after Trump blocks project | Ørsted seeks to force American officials to allow it to finish a $1.5bn project near Rhode Island
-
Lloyd’s of London reverses net zero ban | Insurers no longer have to meet targets designed to curb support for polluting projects
06:49 AM BST
What happened overnight
Good morning
Thanks for joining me.
On Wall Street, the S&P 500 gained 0.8pc, to finish at 6,502.08. The Dow Jones rose by a similar percentage, to 45,621.29pc, while the Nasdaq gained 1pc, to end at 21,707.69.
In the bond market, the yield on benchmark 10-year US Treasury notes fell to 4.162pc from 4.222pc late on Wednesday.

title: Target Corporation ( TGT ): A Bull Case Theory
description: Target Corporation ( TGT ): A Bull Case Theory
text:
We came across a bullish thesis on Target Corporation on Business Invest’s Substack by Francesco Ferrari. In this article, we will summarize the bulls’ thesis on TGT. Target Corporation's share was trading at $95.98 as of August 29th. TGT’s trailing and forward P/E were 11.19 and 13.05 respectively according to Yahoo Finance.
Copyright: nicoletaionescu / 123RF Stock Photo
Target Corporation (TGT) has seen a sharp decline, down roughly 65% from its 2021 highs, drawing attention during its latest earnings release. Initial analysis suggested an asymmetric risk-reward setup, with a bear scenario near $86 and a bull case of $205, underpinned by modest assumptions for sales growth, forward margins, multiples, and buybacks. This superficially attractive setup briefly tempted an investor, but deeper qualitative analysis revealed several warning signs. These included a CEO transition with minimal insider ownership, flat to negative comparable store sales, declining transaction volumes, stagnant digital sales since 2022, and weakening pricing power amidst inflation and looming tariffs.
Market share losses across multiple categories further highlighted underlying operational challenges. Risk assessment tools flagged at least 17 yellow and red indicators, while management commentary on operational levers was vague and unconvincing, with odd prioritization of dividend policy and avoidance of buybacks. These factors implied that relying purely on multiples to justify upside could be misleading, potentially creating a value trap, with revised risk-reward scenarios dropping the bear price to $60 and the bull case to $160. Ultimately, the exercise highlighted the tension between short-term valuation appeal and long-term operational reality.
The investor recognized the pull of quick value trades but reaffirmed adherence to principles and a disciplined investment style, emphasizing that potential short-term gains should not override rigorous analysis and alignment with a consistent, quality-focused strategy. Target’s situation underscores the importance of integrating quantitative risk-reward metrics with qualitative business assessment to avoid misjudging fundamentally challenged stocks.
Previously we covered a bullish thesis on Target Corporation (TGT) by LongYield in May 2025, which highlighted digital momentum, cost control, and long-term strategy despite near-term sales weakness and margin pressures. The stock has appreciated roughly 1.7% since then. Francesco Ferrari shares a similar approach but emphasizes deeper operational risks, management concerns, and the potential for a value trap despite attractive multiples.

title: Argan , Inc . ( AGX ): A Bull Case Theory
description: Argan , Inc . ( AGX ): A Bull Case Theory
text:
We came across a bullish thesis on Argan, Inc. on Pound the Rock Investing’s Substack. In this article, we will summarize the bulls’ thesis on AGX. Argan, Inc.'s share was trading at $228.22 as of August 29th. AGX’s trailing P/E was 31.83 according to Yahoo Finance.
Sophie McAulay/Shutterstock.com
Argan is a specialized holding company with four operating subsidiaries, led by Gemma Power Systems, which focuses on engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) of natural gas-fired power plants and renewable energy projects. Its other subsidiaries—Atlantic Projects Company, The Roberts Company, and Southern Maryland Cable—serve global power installations, heavy industries, and telecom infrastructure.
Despite appearing as a diverse collection of engineering firms, Argan operates as a mini-conglomerate in mission-critical infrastructure construction, delivering high-margin, long-term projects that require reliability from Day One. This focus generates sticky customer relationships, strong backlogs, and resilient cash flow.
The company is well-positioned to benefit from secular tailwinds such as the AI infrastructure boom, where data centers require massive, reliable power, and natural gas’s role as a bridge fuel, supporting Gemma’s ongoing EPC projects. U.S. infrastructure spending, industrial reshoring, and energy security investments further expand Argan’s project pipeline. The company maintains a clean balance sheet with $525–546 million in cash, zero debt, and a history of strong free cash flow generation, providing financial flexibility to navigate cyclical lumpiness and pursue optionality through buybacks, dividends, or tuck-in M&A.
At $214/share, Argan trades at a premium, reflecting expectations for sustained high margins, backlog growth above $2 billion, and continued on-time execution of complex projects. However, significant risks exist: fixed-price EPC contracts expose the company to cost overruns, supply chain disruptions, international project losses, and disputed receivables. Revenue recognition practices and overseas project execution have previously created accounting and operational concerns, suggesting underlying cash flow may be less robust than headline figures imply.
Despite these risks, Argan represents a compelling small-cap opportunity in cash-rich, mission-critical infrastructure, leveraged to AI-driven power demand and energy transition trends, with potential upside if execution remains disciplined and backlog growth continues.
Previously we covered a bullish thesis on EMCOR Group, Inc. (EME) by CompanyCharts in April 2025, which highlighted the company’s strong U.S. presence, fixed-price contracts, and robust earnings and free cash flow growth. The company's stock price has appreciated by 62.13% since our coverage. Pound the Rock Investing shares a similar focus on infrastructure construction but emphasizes Argan’s niche in mission-critical EPC projects and cash-rich balance sheet.

title: Why DLocal Stock Is Sinking This Week
description: Why DLocal Stock Is Sinking This Week
text:
Key Points
-
DLocal announced that one of its largest shareholders is trimming its stake in the company.
-
The company doesn't receive funds from the secondary offering, so nothing technically changes with its operations.
-
Ultimately, DLocal is firing on all cylinders operationally, so investors shouldn't worry over this drop.
Shares of up-and-coming payment platform DLocal (NASDAQ: DLO) were down 11% this week at 11 a.m. ET, according to data provided by S&P Global Market Intelligence.
On Thursday, the Uruguay-based company announced that a secondary share offering would take place, the sale of 15 million shares at $12.75 per share.
With DLocal's stock price around $14 prior to this news, it was somewhat inevitable that the company's shares would slide closer to the secondary offering price, causing this week's drop.
What does this mean for DLocal?
While this short-term drop temporarily harms all DLocal investors, nothing has fundamentally changed in the company's actual operations.
Instead, its largest shareholder, an affiliate of private equity firm General Atlantic, is simply selling a portion of its shares. Since General Atlantic made its initial minority investment in the company in 2019 -- and will still hold roughly 49 million shares -- I don't believe the offering is an indictment of DLocal.
Investing groups like General Atlantic have a multitude of reasons for selling a given stock, and after a 50% pop over the last year is as good a time as any.
If anything, this week's drop makes me interested in adding to my DLocal position. DLocal connects some of the largest merchants in the world to over 2 billion people in emerging economies from more than 40 countries across Latin America, Africa, and Asia, with its suite of 900-plus payment options.
Growing total payment volume (TPV) by 53% in its latest quarter -- and guiding for 40% to 50% TPV growth in 2025 -- DLocal could prove to be a great long-term buy at just 21 times free cash flow.
Should you invest $1,000 in DLocal right now?
Before you buy stock in DLocal, consider this:
The Motley Fool Stock Advisor analyst team just identified what they believe are the 10 best stocks for investors to buy now… and DLocal wasn’t one of them. The 10 stocks that made the cut could produce monster returns in the coming years.
Consider when Netflix made this list on December 17, 2004... if you invested $1,000 at the time of our recommendation, you’d have $678,148!* Or when Nvidia made this list on April 15, 2005... if you invested $1,000 at the time of our recommendation, you’d have $1,052,193!*

title: Why Palantir Stock Is Sinking Today
description: Why Palantir Stock Is Sinking Today
text:
Key Points
-
The Bureau of Labor Statistics published August jobs numbers this morning that were weaker than expected.
-
While the weak jobs report supports the case for interest-rate cuts, it's also raising questions about the health of the U.S. economy.
-
Insider selling also appears to be pressuring Palantir stock today.
Palantir (NASDAQ: PLTR) stock is pulling back in Friday's trading. The artificial intelligence software leader's share price was down 2.6% as of noon ET amid the backdrop of a 0.5% decline for the S&P 500 and a 0.2% dip for the Nasdaq Composite. The tech company's stock had been down as much as 5.2% earlier in the day.
Palantir stock is moving lower today as investors react to the latest U.S. jobs data and what the figures could mean for the outlook on interest rates and the broader economy. Recent disclosures of stock selling by company insiders also appears to be factoring into the valuation pullback.
Palantir stock slips as the market reacts to jobs data
The Bureau of Labor Statistics published its August jobs report this morning and announced that 22,000 jobs were added in the month. The growth came in significantly below the 75,000 job additions called for by the average economist estimate.
While the weak jobs growth initially powered bullish momentum thanks to the belief that the data points to to an interest rate cut from the Federal Reserve this month, the positive momentum faded as other concerns took the spotlight. It looks likely that the Fed will cut rates this month, but the weak jobs data is prompting sell-offs due to fears that the U.S. economy is weakening.
Insider selling is also weighing on Palantir stock
In a filing submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, Palantir revealed that three company insiders had recently sold stock. Board member Jeffrey Buckley sold 2,803 shares, with the earliest date of sale in the transaction being Aug. 29. Board member Alexander Moore sold 20,100 shares on Sept. 2.
Chief financial officer and treasurer David Glazer also exercised stock warrants on Sept. 2 that allowed him to purchase 37,770 shares of Palantir stock at a price of $4.72 per share, but he then proceeded to sell even more stock the same day. Across eight transactions that day, Glazer sold 81,000 shares of company stock. While insider selling doesn't necessarily mean that a company and its stock are in trouble, recent sales made by company insiders appear to be adding to concerns about Palantir's heavily growth-dependent valuation.

title: What Going On With Boeing Stock Friday
description: What Going On With Boeing Stock Friday
text:
The Boeing Company (NYSE:BA) traded lower Friday. Boeing announced that the company and the Royal Australian Air Force, RAAF, said the MQ-28 Ghost Bat Collaborative Combat Aircraft completed a slate of trials that demonstrate it can operate alongside crewed jets.
The campaign advances Australia’s development of autonomous “loyal wingman” aircraft while offering Boeing a path to fielding a new class of combat mass at lower risk to aircrews.
The RAAF’s Capability Demonstration 2025 series wrapped up in early June — four months ahead of schedule — with the MQ-28 executing mission sets meant to augment existing platforms.
Also Read: Paramount Skydance Turnaround Could Take Years To Materialize, Says Analyst
The effort combined live flights and digital twins, totaling about 150 flight hours and more than 20,000 hours in simulation, to validate core behaviors and readiness.
The Ghost Bat showcased autonomous mission execution; coordinated “multi-ship” operations to generate combat mass; a forward deployment to RAAF Base Tindal; teaming with an E-7A Wedgetail airborne early warning and control aircraft; and data fusion across multiple MQ-28s with onward transmission to a crewed platform.
The design targets the “find, fix, track and target” portions of the air-combat chain while reducing exposure for pilots.
“The RAAF set the task of proving the first four steps in the Air Combat chain for the MQ-28 and we have accomplished that sooner than anticipated,” said Glen Ferguson, MQ-28 global program director. “Completing this work early allows us to accelerate the next phases of development – engage and assess – with an air-to-air weapon shot planned for later this year or in early 2026.The demonstrations have proven the maturity of MQ-28’s capabilities and the utility of CCA’s and their application to the future force mix,” Ferguson said.
Capabilities validated this year will roll into Block 2 aircraft now in production, forming the foundation for an initial operational capability for the RAAF — and potentially allied users.
The next phases focus on weapons employment and assessment to further cement the CCA’s role within the future force mix.
The MQ-28 is Boeing’s flagship autonomous air-combat program and a key pillar in Australia’s push to field sovereign advanced airpower. Finishing ahead of plan and proving teaming, data sharing and distributed operations bolster the case for CCAs as force multipliers amid tightening budgets and contested airspace.
According to Benzinga Pro, BA stock has gained over 40% in the past year. Investors can gain exposure to the stock via Direxion Daily BA Bull 2X Shares (BOEU).

title: Former BlackRock debt head warns  vulture circling Bolivia crisis
description: Former BlackRock debt head warns  vulture circling Bolivia crisis
text:
By Marc Jones and Rodrigo Campos
LONDON/NEW YORK (Reuters) -The former head of emerging-market debt at asset manager BlackRock and grandson of one of Bolivia's most famous presidents is offering to help the winner of next month's presidential election fix the country's debt problems.
The October 19 runoff is between centrist Rodrigo Paz and right-wing former President Jorge "Tuto" Quiroga, who has said the country needs to renegotiate its $14 billion of external borrowings.
Sergio Trigo Paz, who at BlackRock was involved in some of the world's largest sovereign defaults from Argentina to Ukraine, told Reuters that Bolivia's woes meant "the vultures" - distressed debt investors - were now circling.
With the economy in disarray and barely enough foreign exchange reserves to cover two months of imports, the crunch could come in March when the new government faces roughly $380 million worth of debt payments, he said in a telephone interview from Bolivia on Wednesday.
"This is exactly the environment where distressed-debt funds thrive," said Trigo Paz, who returned to Bolivia this year after working in London for two decades. "They buy (bonds) at cents on the dollar, litigate for recovery and wait."
The country's 7.5% bond maturing in 2030 has been trading just below 80 cents on the dollar after a rally on a poor showing by the ruling socialist party in the August 17 first-round voting.
Trigo Paz said there has also been a short squeeze caused by local pension funds, which has caused distortion.
"The macro challenges are not insurmountable ... But at current levels, 80 cents on the dollar would be pricing in perfection," he said.
The election debate is whether the country needs the kind of chainsaw-style reforms Javier Milei has adopted in neighbouring Argentina, or can afford a more gradual approach.
The International Monetary Fund has recommended that Bolivia phase out costly fuel subsidies, ditch its U.S. dollar currency peg and lift capital controls, all measures Trigo Paz backs.
"What is most important is to get ready for what is coming," he said, urging the new government to act swiftly. "Once the IMF are on the other side of the table you are not in control of the steering wheel."
EXPERIENCE
Given Bolivia's history of economic crises and public protests, veterans warn the painful fixes now required will test the resolve of the new government.
Trigo Paz said he would be willing to help tackle the debt problems in a technocrat capacity, though has not been in contact about the possibility with either Rodrigo Paz - a distant cousin - or Quiroga.

title: Texas nurse abandons house deemed  uninhabitable  by inspector . How to protect your number one investment
description: Texas nurse abandons house deemed  uninhabitable  by inspector . How to protect your number one investment
text:
Texas nurse abandons house deemed 'uninhabitable' by inspector. How to protect your number one investment
Moneywise and Yahoo Finance LLC may earn commission or revenue through links in the content below.
Ashley Frazier, a 25-year-old critical care nurse from La Marque, Texas, purchased her first home less than two years ago, thinking she’d found a great deal.
At the time, she was pursuing a dual doctorate and ready to leave her parents’ house. But soon after moving in, she began noticing strange issues — ceiling light fixtures filling with water, her microwave fogging up daily and a consistently damp attic. The house, which was less than three years old, turned out to have a serious humidity problem.
Must Read
-
Thanks to Jeff Bezos, you can now become a landlord for as little as $100 — and no, you don't have to deal with tenants or fix freezers. Here's how
-
I'm 49 years old and have nothing saved for retirement — what should I do? Don't panic. Here are 6 of the easiest ways you can catch up (and fast)
-
Dave Ramsey warns nearly 50% of Americans are making 1 big Social Security mistake — here’s what it is and 3 simple steps to fix it ASAP
“This was supposed to be my dream home, my starter home. It wasn’t supposed to have any problems,” Frazier told KHOU 11 News. “Now I just feel like I’m living in a nightmare.”
Frazier has since moved out of the home after a mold inspector she hired reportedly deemed it uninhabitable.
What caused the mold issue?
After discovering condensation and visible mold in her still-under-warranty home, Frazier contacted the builder, Lennar. The company sent out an HVAC technician and a mold inspector, but concerns grew when they declined to check behind the walls.
“That’s when the red flags started going off,” Frazier told KHOU 11, noting the mold appeared to be coming from inside the walls and cabinets. Around the same time, she began experiencing respiratory issues, and a chest X-ray revealed a developing scar tissue nodule.
Frazier then hired her own mold inspector who found dangerously high mold levels — 2.2 million spores per cubic meter — declaring the home unsafe to live in.
“I moved out immediately,” she said.
Frazier hired a lawyer soon after.
Lennar responded by stating: “We work hard to promptly correct issues that are our responsibility … Unfortunately, despite our repeated efforts, this homeowner has not allowed us to inspect the home since last summer or to perform any proposed remediation.”
Frazier’s attorney countered, explaining that an exhaustive investigation is required for a legal claim. They are nearing completion of the process, and expect a resolution soon.
How to navigate issues with your home — whether you rent or own
Discovering issues like mold growth in your home can be overwhelming, but quick action can help protect both yourself and your finances. Whether you rent or own your home, here’s how to handle deteriorating property conditions.

CVS Health Corporation (CVS), headquartered in Woonsocket, Rhode Island, provides health solutions, including health care and retail pharmacy services. With a market cap of $94 billion, the company offers prescription medications, beauty, personal care, cosmetics, and health care products, as well as pharmacy benefit management (PBM), disease management, and administrative services.
Companies worth $10 billion or more are generally described as “large-cap stocks.” CVS effortlessly fits that bill, with its market cap exceeding this mark, underscoring its size, influence, and dominance within the healthcare plans industry. title: Big Tech AI Buildout Could Be Worth $4 Trillion , and These 2 Semiconductor Stocks Stand to Gain Most
description: Big Tech AI Buildout Could Be Worth $4 Trillion , and These 2 Semiconductor Stocks Stand to Gain Most
text:
The artificial intelligence (AI) boom has been going strong for the past few years as companies aim to apply the game-changing technology to their businesses. Excitement is high because AI could transform processes in offices, factories, and across delivery networks just to mention a few examples. AI also is leading to innovations in industries from pharmaceuticals to automotive, with companies aiming to create life-saving drugs and the safest and most efficient self-driving vehicles.
All of this could generate enormous revenue gains and cost savings for companies across industries. So, it's not surprising that the world's biggest tech players are pouring investment into this high-potential area. Meta Platforms and Alphabet both lifted capital spending forecasts in their recent earnings calls, citing ongoing investment in AI infrastructure. And Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) chief Jensen Huang predicted the AI buildout could be worth $3 trillion to $4 trillion by the end of the decade.
Two semiconductor stocks in particular stand to gain the most from this spending boom. Let's check them out.
1. Nvidia
Nvidia is the world's No. 1 designer of graphics processing units (GPUs), the chip needed to drive key AI tasks -- but the tech giant hasn't stopped there. It's also developed an entire array of AI products and services to suit the needs of any customer, from the big tech player to the small start-up. So Nvidia is positioning itself to be the "go to" destination for companies as they set off on the AI path.
Though Nvidia serves a wide variety of AI players in the market, it's important to note that a great deal of its sales comes from technology giants such as Meta, Alphabet, and Microsoft. Though Nvidia doesn't name its biggest customers, these players each have publicly spoken of their relationship with Nvidia -- and each of these companies is spending big on AI. For example, Meta predicts $66 billion to $72 billion in capital spending this year, and much of this investment will support AI buildout.
These technology powerhouses aim to build the best AI platforms and do so in the most efficient manner, and today, the company offering chips and related products and services to do so is Nvidia. In the latest quarter, Nvidia reported double-digit revenue growth and called demand for its latest chip Blackwell Ultra "extraordinary," so it's clear tech giants continue to flock to this AI leader. And Nvidia's plan to update its chips annually should keep this trend going.
All of this means, as the AI buildout continues toward potentially $4 trillion, Nvidia is likely to be one of the biggest winners.
2. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing
Nvidia may design chips, but to bring those chips to market, it relies on Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (NYSE: TSM). And so do many other companies, from Advanced Micro Devices to Broadcom. In fact, TSMC produces about 90% of today's advanced chips, according to an article in Wired. Therefore, the chip manufacturer benefits not only from Nvidia's strength, but from every chip designer's growth during this AI boom.
On top of this, TSMC is taking steps to invest more in U.S.-based production, a move that should shield the company and its customers from import tariffs down the road. TSMC this year announced $165 billion in investment in chip manufacturing in the U.S. -- this includes the development of six advanced wafer production fabs in Arizona, two packaging fabs, and a research and development center. The first fab already is producing at volume, construction of the second fab is complete, and construction of the third has started. These moves should streamline the process of working with U.S. chip designers and help TSMC keep up with demand as infrastructure spending increases.
The chipmaker has a solid earnings track record, generating double-digit growth quarter after quarter, and in its recent earnings report said it expects ongoing strength in AI demand -- this is as both companies and countries increase their spending on chips and related products and services. All of this bodes well for TSMC, making it a fantastic stock to buy and hold throughout the AI revolution.
Should you buy stock in Nvidia right now?
Before you buy stock in Nvidia, consider this:
The Motley Fool Stock Advisor analyst team just identified what they believe are the 10 best stocks for investors to buy now… and Nvidia wasn’t one of them. The 10 stocks that made the cut could produce monster returns in the coming years.
Consider when Netflix made this list on December 17, 2004... if you invested $1,000 at the time of our recommendation, you’d have $654,759!* Or when Nvidia made this list on April 15, 2005... if you invested $1,000 at the time of our recommendation, you’d have $1,046,799!*
Now, it’s worth noting Stock Advisor’s total average return is 1,042% — a market-crushing outperformance compared to 183% for the S&P 500. Don’t miss out on the latest top 10 list, available when you join Stock Advisor.
